leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,495] r 7.1 Resignation of liquidator (Corporations Act s 473(1))

p.text: A liquidator appointed by the Court who wishes to resign office must file with the Registrar, and lodge with ASIC, a memorandum of resignation.
[subr (1) am Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 16 May 2008]
The resignation takes effect on the filing and lodging of the memorandum.
[r 7.1 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
Legislation cited in [15,495.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 473(1), s 502, s 503, s 530.

A liquidator may resign under s 473(1) of the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth). The resignation takes effect when the notice of resignation has been filed with the Registrar of the court and lodged with ASIC: Re Free [2010] NSWSC 1079; BC201006900 at [10] per Barrett J. In the case of a sole liquidator resigning it may be appropriate to make an order appointing a new liquidator having immediate effect but expressed to fill the vacancy to arise upon completion of the r 7.1 steps: Re Free [2010] NSWSC 1079; BC201006900 at [11]. Where one of two liquidators resigns in a creditor’s voluntary winding up the second original appointee continues following the resignation of the other appointee: s 530 Corporations Act. However to install the second liquidator the procedure is effected by removing both existing liquidators under s 503 and appointing the proposed liquidators under the same section, because s 502 allows the court to make an appointment only where “no liquidator is acting”: Re Free [2010] NSWSC 1079; BC201006900 at [21].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,500] r 7.2 Filling vacancy in office of liquidator (Corporations Act s 473(7), s 502)

p.text: If, for any reason, there is no liquidator acting in a winding up, the Court may:
in the case of a winding up by the Court — appoint another official liquidator whose written consent in accordance with Form 8 has been filed; and
in the case of a voluntary winding up — appoint another registered liquidator whose written consent in accordance with Form 8 has been filed.
The Court may make the appointment:
in any case — on application by ASIC, a creditor or a contributory; or
in the case of a winding up by the Court — on its own initiative.
[subr (2) am Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 16 May 2008]
[r 7.2 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
Legislation cited in [15,500.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 Section 502.

The status granted by r 7.2(2)(a) is not exhaustive. Section 502 of the Corporations Act confers a general power to appoint a liquidator in a winding up. The court may exercise the power on the application of any person with a relevant proper interest: Re Tumut River Orchard Management Ltd (in liq) [2011] NSWSC 915; BC201106164 at [11]–[13] (application by equitable assignee of company loans).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,505] r 7.3 Report to liquidator as to company’s affairs (Corporations Act s 475)

leg:heading.title: Report to liquidator as to company’s affairs (Corporations Act s 475 )

p.text: If a person is required under section 475 of the Corporations Act to submit and verify a report as to the affairs of a company, the liquidator must give to the person the appropriate forms and instructions for the preparation of the report.
[subr (1) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
Except by order of the Court, no person is to be allowed out of the property of a company any costs or expenses incurred in relation to the preparation of the report that have not been:
sanctioned by the liquidator before being incurred; or
taxed or assessed.
The liquidator must report to the Court any default in complying with the requirements of section 475 of the Corporations Act.
[subr (3) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
In this rule:
includes a provisional liquidator.
[r 7.3 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,510] r 7.4 Liquidator to file certificate and copy of settled list of contributories (Corporations Act s 478)

leg:heading.title: Liquidator to file certificate and copy of settled list of contributories (Corporations Act s 478 )

p.text: If, in a winding up by the Court, a liquidator has settled and certified a list, or supplementary list, of contributories, the liquidator must, within 14 days after doing so, file the certificate and a copy of the list.
[r 7.4 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]

The court may properly dispense with the settlement of the list in an appropriate case — such as where creditors have been paid in full, there is very small number of shareholders and it is possible to establish that the position is perfectly clear without going through the formalities prescribed by the rules: CGU Workers Compensation (NSW) Ltd v Ascom Service Automation (Aust) Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 747; BC200505322 at [4] per Barrett J (citing Buckley J in Re Paragon Holdings Ltd [1961] 1 Ch 346 at 353).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,515] r 7.5 Release of liquidator and deregistration of company (Corporations Act s 480(c) and (d))

p.text: This rule applies to an application by the liquidator of a company:
for an order that the liquidator be released; or
for an order that the liquidator be released and that ASIC deregister the company.
[subr (1) am Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 16 May 2008]
The interlocutory process seeking the order must include:

a notice stating that any objection to the release of the liquidator must be made by filing and serving a notice of objection, in the prescribed form, within 21 days after the date of service of the interlocutory process; and
a statement setting out the terms of subsection 481(3) of the Corprorations Act.

Subsection 481(3) of the Corporations Act provides that an order of the Court releasing a liquidator discharges the liquidator from all liability in respect of any act done or default made by the liquidator in the administration of the affairs of the company, or otherwise in relation to the liquidator’s conduct as liquidator, but any such order may be revoked on proof that it was obtained by fraud or by suppression or by concealment of any material fact.
[subr (2) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
The supporting affidavit must include details of the following matters:

whether the whole of the company’s property has been realised or whether so much of the company’s property has been realised as, in the liquidator’s opinion, can be realised without needlessly protracting the winding up;
any calls made on contributories in the course of the winding up;
any dividends paid in the course of the winding up;
whether the committee of inspection (if any) has passed a resolution approving the liquidator’s release;
whether the Court has ordered a report on the accounts of the liquidator to be prepared;
whether any objection to the release of the liquidator has been received by the liquidator from:
an auditor appointed by ASIC or by the Court; or
any creditor, contributory or other interested person;
whether the liquidator considers it necessary to report on the affairs of the company or any of its officers;
any property disclaimed in the course of the winding up;
any remuneration paid or payable to the liquidator and how such remuneration was determined;
any costs, charges or expenses payable by the liquidator if the Court grants the liquidator’s release;
if the application is made under paragraph 480(c) of the Corporations Act — the facts and circumstances by reason of which it is submitted that the company should not be deregistered.
[subr (3) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004 ; Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 16 May 2008]
The liquidator must include in the supporting affidavit the statements set out in paragraphs (a) and (b) of this subrule, including, if appropriate, the words in brackets:

“To the best of my belief, there has been no act done or default made by me in the administration of the affairs of the subject corporation or otherwise in relation to my conduct as liquidator which is likely to give rise to any liability to the subject corporation or any creditor or contributory [except as disclosed in this affidavit]”;
“I am not aware of any claim made by any person that there has been any such act or default [except as disclosed in this affidavit]”.
The liquidator must file with, or annex to, the supporting affidavit:
a statement of the financial position of the company at the date when the interlocutory process seeking release was filed; and
a summary of the liquidator’s receipts and payments in winding up the company.

Unless the Court otherwise orders, the liquidator must serve by prepaid post, on each creditor who has proved a debt in the course of the winding up, and on each contributory, a copy of the interlocutory process accompanied by:
a copy of the summary of the liquidator’s receipts and payments in winding up the company; and
a copy of the statement of the financial position of the company at the date when the interlocutory process seeking release was filed.
[r 7.5 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
Legislation cited in [15,515.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 488(2).

There is a useful discussion of the practice and procedure in relation to applications for release of a liquidator in Re Autistic Therapy Society of Queensland Ltd (in liq) (1981) 5 ACLR 658; (1981) CLC ¶40-735 ; Re Budget Floor Coverings Pty Ltd (in liq) (1982) 6 ACLR 657; 1 ACLC 313 ; Singer v Trustee of the property of Munro [1981] 3 All ER 215; [1981] 1 WLR 1358 . The court may not make an order for dissolution except in conjunction with an order for release of the liquidator: Re Austral Family Homes Pty Ltd (in liq) (1992) 28 NSWLR 247; 8 ACSR 322; 10 ACLC 1125 in which alternative courses of action for dissolution are discussed. The court may consider and excuse irregularities by the liquidator in the conduct of the liquidation upon an application for release: eg, CGU Workers Compensation (NSW) Ltd v Ascom Service Automation (Aust) Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 747; BC200505322 (failure to seek leave under s 488(2) before paying the surplus to a sole contributory).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,520] r 7.6 Objection to release of liquidator — Form 13

leg:heading.title: Objection to release of liquidator — Form 13

p.text: A creditor or contributory of a company who wishes to object to the release of the liquidator of the company must, within 21 days after the date of service of the interlocutory process seeking release:
file:
a notice of objection in accordance with Form 13 ; and
if appropriate, an affidavit stating any facts relied on; and
serve a copy of the notice and the affidavit (if any) on the liquidator.

If the liquidator is served with a notice of objection by a creditor or contributory, the liquidator must, within 3 days after being served, serve on the creditor or contributory a copy of the affidavit supporting the interlocutory process.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,525] r 7.7 Report on accounts of liquidator (Corporations Act s 481)

leg:heading.title: Report on accounts of liquidator (Corporations Act s 481 )

p.text: If the Court orders that a report on the accounts of a liquidator be prepared under subsection 481(1) of the Corporations Act, the liquidator must give to the auditor appointed to prepare the report all information, books and vouchers required to prepare the report.
[subr (1) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
On completing the report, the auditor must:
file a copy of the report in a sealed envelope that is marked with the title and number of the proceeding and the words “Auditor’s report under subsection 481(1) of the Corporations Act 2001”; and
serve a copy of the report on the liquidator; and
lodge a copy of the report with ASIC.
[subr (2) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004 ; Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 16 May 2008]
Except with the leave of the Court, a report is not available for inspection by any person except the liquidator or ASIC.
[r 7.7 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004 ; Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 16 May 2008]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,530] r 7.8 Application for payment of call (Corporations Act s 483(3)(b)) — Form 14

leg:heading.title: Application for payment of call (Corporations Act s 483(3)(b) ) — Form 14

p.text: The affidavit in support of an application by the liquidator of a company, under paragraph 483(3)(b) of the Corporations Act, for an order for the payment of a call must be in accordance with Form 14 .
[r 7.8 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,535] r 7.9 Distribution of surplus by liquidator with special leave of the Court (Corporations Act s 488(2)) — Form 15

leg:heading.title: Distribution of surplus by liquidator with special leave of the Court (Corporations Act s 488(2) ) — Form 15

p.text: The affidavit in support of an application for special leave to distribute a surplus must state how the liquidator intends to distribute the surplus including the name and address of each person to whom the liquidator intends to distribute any part of the surplus.
At least 14 days before the date fixed for hearing of the application, the liquidator must publish a notice of the application.
The notice must be:
in accordance with Form 15 ; and
published in accordance with rule 2.11 .
[r 7.9 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
Legislation cited in [15,535.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 1322(4), s 488(2).

A liquidator can only distribute a surplus with the court's "special leave" under s 488(2) of the Corporations Act. This means that the liquidator must make a specific application for leave, and not merely include the application with other administrative matters: Re Klaus Maertin Pty Ltd (in liq); Maertin v Klaus Maertin Pty Ltd (2009) 232 FLR 239; [2009] NSWSC 618; BC200905705 at [40] per Austin J citing Re DS Millard & Son Pty Ltd (1997) 24 ACSR 71; 15 ACLC 808; BC9702185 per Young J.

The failure to obtain special leave before making a distribution of surplus assets is an irregularity which can be cured retrospectively. In simple cases where creditors have been paid in full and there are few contributories the court may make excuse a failure to obtain leave under s 488(2) and make orders under s 1322(4) in respect of that irregularity: CGU Workers Compensation (NSW) Ltd v Ascom Service Automation (Aust) Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 747; BC200505322 at [4] [7] per Barrett J. But no such order should be made if the distribution has excluded a person with an arguable claim to be a contributory: Re Klaus Maertin Pty Ltd (in liq); Maertin v Klaus Maertin Pty Ltd, above, at [40]–[48]. Section 488(1) and UCPR 7.10 are qualified by Corporations Regulations 2001 reg 5.6.71(1), which direct that the order authorising distribution of surplus should include Form 551 schedule providing information about the distribution and the persons to whom the distribution is paid. The court has the power to dispense with this in simple cases: Re Klaus Maertin Pty Ltd (in liq); Maertin v Klaus Maertin Pty Ltd, above, at [51] (schedule dispensed with); Brealey v Shields [2009] NSWSC 1148; BC200909675 at [8]–[15] per Barrett J (schedule dispensed with); Re FAI Car Owners Mutual Insurance Co Pty Ltd (2009) 262 ALR 552; 76 ACSR 164; [2009] NSWSC 1350; BC200910984 at [28] per Barrett J (schedule dispensed with).

The purpose of requiring the court’s special leave is primarily to ensure that there is in fact a surplus to be distributed. The purpose of the requirement that notice of the application be advertised is to enable creditors or contributories not otherwise on notice to come in, even belatedly, and oppose a distribution of surplus: Visnic v Sywak [2012] NSWSC 1284; BC201210554 at [3], [5] per Brereton J. However, the court may in appropriate cases dispense with that requirement: Visnic v Sywak, above at [5] (advertising dispensed with where winding up on foot for five years and unlikely that no creditors had not come forward).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,540] r 7.10 Powers delegated to liquidator by the Court (Corporations Act s 488)

leg:heading.title: Powers delegated to liquidator by the Court (Corporations Act s 488 )

p.text: Subject to the Corporations Act , the Corporations Regulations, these Rules, and any order of the Court, the powers and duties conferred or imposed on the Court by Part 5.4B of the Corporations Act in respect of the matters mentioned in subsection 488(1) of the Corporations Act may be exercised or performed by a liquidator appointed by the Court as an officer of the Court and subject to the control of the Court.
[r 7.10 am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
Legislation cited in [15.540.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 485(2), s 488(1), s 488(2).
(CTH) Corporations Regulations 2001 regs 5.6.58, 5.6.62.

In a court-ordered winding up, the court has the responsibility of adjusting the rights of the contributories among themselves and distributing any surplus among the persons entitled to it: see s 485(2) Corporations Act 2001. Section 488(1) Corporations Act 2001 contemplates that rules or regulations may allow that function to be performed by the liquidator. Corporations Regulations 2001 regs 5.6.58 to 5.6.62 allow the liquidator to settle the list of contributories but, apart from s 488(2) (its statement that the liquidator “may distribute surplus” only with the leave of the court) there is no express grant of power to a liquidator to distribute surplus. Section 488(2), by regulating distribution by the liquidator, recognises that the liquidator has the power (albeit a controlled power) to distribute. The provisions with respect to distribution of surplus have the twofold aim of ensuring that there is in reality a surplus (in that the claims of creditors have been recognised and met in full) and of seeing that the correct relativities among the contributories have been observed, having regard to the possibility of differing rights: CGU Workers Compensation (NSW) Ltd v Ascom Service Automation (Aust) Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 747; BC200505322 at [3] –[4] per Barrett J.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15,545] r 7.11 Inquiry into conduct of liquidator (Corporations Act s 536(1) and (2))

leg:heading.title: Inquiry into conduct of liquidator (Corporations Act s 536(1) and (2))

p.text: A complaint to the Court under paragraph 536(1)(b) of the Corporations Act must be made:
in the case of a winding up by the Court — by an interlocutory process seeking an inquiry; and
in the case of a voluntary winding up — by an originating process seeking an inquiry.
[subr (1) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
A report to the Court by ASIC under subsection 536(2) of the Corporations Act must be made:
in the case of a winding up by the Court — by filing:
an interlocutory process seeking orders under the subsection; and
a written report in a sealed envelope that is marked with the title and number of the proceeding; and
in the case of a voluntary winding up — by filing:
an originating process seeking orders under the subsection; and
a written report in a sealed envelope that is marked with the title of the proceeding and provision for its number.
[subr (2) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004 ; Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 16 May 2008]
The contents of a report filed under subrule (2) need not, at the time of filing, be verified by an affidavit.
Except with the leave of the Court, a report made under subsection 536(2) of the Corporations Act is not available for inspection by any person except the liquidator or ASIC.
[subr (4) am Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004 ; Gaz 53 of 16 May 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 16 May 2008]
In this rule:
includes a provisional liquidator.
[r 7.11 am Gaz 168 of 22 December 2000 p 13608 ; Gaz 197 of 19 December 2003 p 11377, effective 1 January 2004]
